title: Â¿QuÃ© tiempo harÃ¡ en Galicia en Fin de AÃ±o?
text: Los Ãºltimos dÃ­as de 2023 estarÃ¡n marcados en Galicia por una profunda borrasca situada al oeste de Irlanda. Sin embargo, el mal tiempo darÃ¡ una tregua justo para celebrar el Fin de AÃ±o. Esta es la predicciÃ³n de MeteoGalicia. La predicciÃ³n para el sÃ¡bado 30 de diciembre La entrada de un frente atlÃ¡ntico por el noroeste producirÃ¡ este sÃ¡bado precipitaciones dÃ©biles y dispersas en Galicia. Al final de la jornada se esperan fuertes vientos. Este temporal obligÃ³ a activar la alerta naranja en la costa de A CoruÃ±a por mar de viento. En la de Lugo y Pontevedra el aviso serÃ¡ amarillo por vientos de fuerza 7. En tierra tambiÃ©n habrÃ¡ alerta amarilla en las comarcas costeras de A MariÃ±a y A CoruÃ±a, ademÃ¡s de en las zonas de montaÃ±a de Lugo y Ourense, por vientos de mÃ¡s de 80 km/h. Las temperaturas serÃ¡n propias de la Ã©poca, con mÃ­nimas que oscilarÃ¡n desde los 5 grados en Lugo a los 9Âº en Pontevedra y mÃ¡ximas que alcanzarÃ¡n los 16Âº en Ferrol y A CoruÃ±a. La predicciÃ³n para el domingo 31 de diciembre El temporal remitirÃ¡ el Ãºltimo dÃ­a del aÃ±o, con el tiempo justo para celebrar Nochevieja sin lluvia. La situaciÃ³n, apunta MeteoGalicia, serÃ¡ tranquila en tierra durante el domingo, aunque en el mar las olas continuarÃ¡n superando los cuatro metros en mar abierto. Venres e sÃ¡bado agardamos tempo tranquilo. Pero, como virÃ¡ aâ€” MeteoGalicia (@MeteoGalicia) [#Noitevella]ðŸ¥³? Estaremos entre dÃºas borrascas: A primeira deixarÃ¡ chuvia na maÃ±Ã¡ do 31 e a segunda na maÃ±Ã¡ do dÃ­a 1. No medio quedarÃ­a tempo seco e frÃ­o. Pero todo pende dun fÃ­o. Atentos Ã¡s pantallasðŸ˜‰ [pic.twitter.com/zhRVYnjZKi] [December 28, 2023] La predicciÃ³n para el lunes 1 de enero El aÃ±o arrancarÃ¡ de nuevo con lluvias. A partir del lunes regresarÃ¡n las precipitaciones en Galicia. Y no habrÃ¡ cambios en los primeros dÃ­as de 2024, en los que se espera que el cielo estÃ© condicionado por un tren de borrascas.

author: Jeff Stitt
title: 96-year-old sends 8,000 handwritten holiday cards to U.S. troops
text:
MCPHERSON, Kansas (Video from KAKE, FAMILY PHOTOS, MARY PETERSON, CNN, Family Photos/Mary Peterson) â€” A 96-year-old Kansas woman who comes from a military family annually sends thousands of holiday cards to members of the military who canâ€™t be home for the holidays.
"I think only had 7,000 the first year. But then I had 8,000 last year and 8,000 again this year,â€ Mary Peterson of McPherson, Kansas, told KAKE .
Advertisement Mary has been sending the cards to troops since 2020. In that time, more than 23,000 cards have been delivered to U.S. Army Fort Riley in North Central Kansas and then sent around the world to those who serve in the military.
Keeping the arts of handwriting and letter-writing alive, the cards â€” which bear messages written in beautiful cursive writing â€” say things like, "God bless you and keep you safe. That is my prayer for you. Grandma Mary, McPherson, Kansas."
She hopes military members hold the cards near and dear.
"I hope that makes them realize that there's somebody that still loves them and loves what they're doing,â€ she said.
And, Mary hopes the cards hold special meaning for troops who donâ€™t regularly receive letters.
"There's so many heartaches and broken homes and people went to the service because it was something else for them to do. And they won't hear from family because they've lost their connection,â€ she explained to KAKE.
Grandfather reads bedtime stories to thousands of kids on YouTube While sheâ€™s been sending the cards since 2020, Mary is no stranger to sending letters to soldiers.
Thatâ€™s because, when Mary was in high school, her older brother served overseas, and she was sure to send him a weekly letter.
Her husband also served in World War II and she said she knows what itâ€™s like to have a loved one overseas during the holidays.
Mary told KAKE that her age wonâ€™t stop her from keeping up her tradition of sending handwritten cards and that she will continue to send them to troops for as long as her hands will let her write.
She said she can write about 50 cards per day. She starts filling them out in the summertime, according to KAKEâ€™s reporting.
Mary isnâ€™t alone in her mission of getting cards in the hands of U.S. military members. Annually, members of the local community, which is located around 62 miles outside of Wichita, donate blank cards.
See more in the video player above.

author: Christopher Reynolds; The Canadian Press
title: Canada Jetlines becomes latest victim of cutthroat airline sector
text:
Less than two years after it first hit the skies, Canada Jetlines has grounded its planes and ceased operations amid a cash crisis that caused it to become the third Canadian carrier in less than a year to stop flying.
The low-cost airline, which flew mainly to sun destinations out of Toronto on top of leases and charter trips, said Thursday it failed to find the capital needed to stay afloat and planned to file for creditor protection.
"The company ... pursued all available financing alternatives including strategic transactions and equity and debt financings," said spokeswoman Erica Dymond in a release.
"Unfortunately despite these efforts, the company has been unable to obtain the financing required to continue operations at this time."
Passengers with existing bookings should contact their credit card company to secure refunds, she said. "Every effort is being made to assist passengers at this time."
Trading of the company's shares on the NEO Exchange was halted late Wednesday afternoon.
The shutdown follows the resignation of four board members on Monday, including chairwoman and CEO Brigitte Goersch.
It signals yet another airline departure from Canadian skies after the closure of Lynx Air in February and budget carrier Swoop last October as concerns about domestic competition persist.
"Any time you lose some competition in the Canadian market it's kind of sad for the travellers, because it puts less pressure on prices," said Jacques Roy, a professor of transport management at HEC Montreal business school.
Founded in 2013 as a would-be charter airline, Canada Jetlines accounted for only a fraction of scheduled flights to sun destinations, he qualified.
The shutdown also underscores the challenges of running a carrier in a vast country with a diffuse population and only a few key air travel hubs.
"Every time a new player wants to enter the market, there's only one certainty: they're going to be losing money for the first eight, nine, 10 months at least, and perhaps even more. So you need a good bank account," said Roy, noting that leisure travellers are particularly price-sensitive.
"The major players will play the game of meeting your fares. And if you reduce your fares below your cost, then that's a recipe for failure in the short term," he said.
"It's a tough market."
Until Thursday, Jetlines was flying a few dozen flights per month from Toronto to Miami and Orlando, Fla., as well as Cancun, Mexico, according to aviation tracking firm Cirium.
It also flew charter flights, including for three Canadian Football League teams. The airline signed contracts with the Ottawa Redblacks, Hamilton Tiger-Cats and Toronto Argonauts that saw it haul players to select away games last season. The Redblacks contract was a three-year deal that may no longer be fulfilled.
Thursday's halt leaves only one budget carrier left in Canada â€” Flair Airlines â€” alongside the other major players: Air Canada, WestJet, Porter Airlines, Air Transat and the WestJet-owned Sunwing Airlines.
Last month, competition commissioner Matthew Boswell launched a market study of domestic airline service amid passengers' ongoing frustration with prices and quality.
Canada Jetlines, which has struggled to get more than a handful of planes off the ground since its inaugural flight in September 2022, faced a series of hiccups even before this week's turbulence.
On June 30, Eddy Doyle stepped down as CEO after taking on the role in 2021. In October 2022, former Quebec premier Jean Charest resigned from the board.
The challenges it faced in its home market were evident.
In January 2023, it pressed pause on domestic routes as the carrier refocused on sun destinations and leasing its planes, but said at the time it aimed to resume in-country flights that fall.
Last April, it signed over a pair of Airbus narrow-body jets to a European carrier for most of the remaining year in a so-called wet lease â€” where the lessor furnishes the aircraft, crew, maintenance and insurance for another company. It also deployed two more planes for flights between Morocco and Western Europe in a three-month agreement with Air Arabia.
In October 2019, the Mississauga, Ont.-based company announced it was postponing its planned December launch and laying off most employees after failing to secure the required financing and losing investment partners. The delay wound up dragging on for nearly three years, thanks in part to the COVID-19 pandemic.
That 2019 setback followed six years of fundraising and despite Ottawa lifting the foreign ownership ceiling on Canadian airlines to 49 per cent from 25 per cent in 2018, allowing for a wider pool of investors.
Canada Jetlines lost $14.2 million over the 12 months between March 2023 and last March, though it eked out a profit in one of the quarters, according to financial filings. Quarterly revenues ranged between $8 million and $12 million.
In May, the company secured a $2-million loan from Square Financial Investment Corp., a Mississauga-based holding company owned by board member Reg Christian, who was named executive vice-president as a result.
Jetlines had a $38.3-million deficit and negative working capital of $14.9 million as of March 31.
As recently as May 10, the company said in financial statements it planned to grow to seven planes by year's end and 15 aircraft by 2026.
This report by The Canadian Press was first published Aug. 15, 2024.
Christopher Reynolds, The Canadian Press

author: agnes.
title: Bluesky \u00e8 in fiamme, Meta \u00e8 gelosa\u2026
text: Bluesky ha 15 milioni di utenti. Questo Ã¨ il numero totale di nuovi utenti che Threads ha aggiunto in un mese, dice il suo capo. Bluesky potrebbe essere in crescita, ma a Meta non vogliamo che le persone dimentichino Instagram e Threads. Il loro manager, Adam Mosseri, tiene a sottolineare che Threads Ã¨ ancora piÃ¹ imponente. In un post di giovedÃ¬, Mosseri ha affermato che Threads ha registrato â€œoltre 15 milioni di iscrizioni solo nel mese di novembreâ€, minimizzando cosÃ¬ lâ€™annuncio di Bluesky di aver raggiunto 15 milioni di utenti totali mercoledÃ¬. Meta ha inoltre ribadito che la piattaforma registra piÃ¹ di 1 milione di iscrizioni al giorno, una statistica rivelata dal suo CEO Mark Zuckerberg durante la presentazione degli utili del mese scorso. Ha inoltre osservato che la piattaforma osserva questo volume di registrazioni da â€œtre mesiâ€. Molti utenti si sono rivolti a Bluesky alla ricerca di una nuova piattaforma per abbandonare X. Sulla rete sempre piÃ¹ politicizzata di Elon Musk, gli utenti hanno espresso preoccupazioni riguardo allâ€™incentivazione del coinvolgimento, alla moderazione dei problemi, alla disinformazione e al feed di notizie algoritmico. Alcune critiche sono rivolte anche a Threads. Adam Mosseri ha riconosciuto che â€œabbiamo ancora molto lavoro da fareâ€ e ha affermato che i team dellâ€™azienda â€œstanno lavorando duramente per fornire a questa comunitÃ  ciÃ² di cui ha bisognoâ€. Meta prevede di introdurre presto annunci pubblicitari su Threads, che potrebbero non essere ben accolti. Meta ha anche riferito che Threads non chiede piÃ¹ ai nuovi utenti se vogliono seguire tutti quelli che giÃ  seguono su Instagram. â€œÃˆ da un poâ€™ che stiamo eseguendo un test e sembra che le persone preferiscano costruire una rete diversa su Threads rispetto a quella che hanno su Instagramâ€, ha detto il suo rappresentante. AdamAnd Mosseri sembra essere aperto allâ€™esplorazione di un sistema di messaggistica privato specifico per i thread. In questo momento, la messaggistica privata Ã¨ uno dei maggiori vantaggi di Bluesky rispetto a Threads. Business

author: /news/author/tiprankshongkongnewsdesk
title: Genor Biopharma Extends CEO's Term to Strengthen Leadership
text:
An update from Genor Biopharma Holdings Limited ( (HK:6998) ) is now available.
Genor Biopharma Holdings Limited has announced the extension of Dr. Guo Fengâ€™s term as CEO for an additional two years, effective from April 16, 2025, to April 15, 2027. This decision reflects the companyâ€™s confidence in Dr. Guoâ€™s leadership and his extensive experience in the biopharmaceutical industry, which is expected to benefit the companyâ€™s strategic direction and operational management.
More about Genor Biopharma Holdings Limited
Genor Biopharma Holdings Limited is a company in the biopharmaceutical industry, focusing on the development and commercialization of innovative biologics. The company operates primarily in the research and development sector, aiming to advance treatments in various therapeutic areas.

author: OWARDEN@RANDB.COM (Owen Warden)
title: Georgia offensive line coach Stacey Searels hospitalized with pneumonia
text:
On Wednesday, Georgia football offensive line coach Stacey Searels was announced to have been hospitalized with pneumonia after not traveling with the team to Miami, Florida. Searelsis expected to make a full recovery.
Searels is in his second year with Georgia as the teamâ€™s offensive line coach and has helped the unit be finalists for the Joe Moore Award â€” which is given to the best offensive line unit in college football â€” for the past two seasons.
Georgia offensive analyst Manrey Saint-Amour will step in during Searelsâ€™ absence. Saint-Amour was previously an offensive line coach at Charleston Southern in 2022 and served as an offensive line graduate assistant at both Alabama and Florida State before then. Saint-Amour was formerly a center with Georgia Southern, in which he made 36 career starts and was a first-team All-Sun Belt selection as a senior in 2014.
While Searels didnâ€™t travel, new Georgia defensive backs coach Donte Williams did travel with the team and was coaching the secondary at practice.
Additionally, certain players did not travel with the team. Right tackle Amarius Mims did not travel with the team and will seemingly not play on Saturday. Tight end Brock Bowers is working back from his ankle injury, but the tight ends coach Todd Hartley said he may play if he returns to full health. Freshman edge rusher Damon Wilson Jr. also didnâ€™t travel due to receiving knee surgery.
While those three did not make the trip, several others did, including several incoming freshmen that have been practicing with the team leading up to the trip.
Cornerback Daniel Harris and kicker Jared Zirkel, who both entered the transfer portal, also made the trip down and unlike those previously mentioned, can play.
Both Ladd McConkey and Julian Humphrey were both questionable to play in this game due to injury, but both were on the field. Humphrey was specifically in a black non-contact jersey, while McConkey wasnâ€™t, signaling that the redshirt junior would likely play on Saturday against the Seminoles. McConkey confirmed on Thursday that he will play.
While Georgia seemingly only has one hold-out in Mims, Florida Stateâ€™s holdouts include Keon Coleman, Johnny Wilson, tight end Jaheim Bell and running back Trey Benson on offense and defensive lineman Fabien Lovett and Jared Verse and cornerback Akeem Dent on defense. Quarterback Tate Rodemaker, who initially started for injured starter Jordan Travis, will also not play after entering the transfer portal.
Freshman Brock Glenn, who started in the ACC Championship and had a rough performance, will make his second start against Georgia. Against Louisville, Glenn had an abysmal 38% completion rate, 55 yards and no touchdowns.
Both teams will be working with depleted quarterback rooms after transfers departed the team. Georgia likely holds the advantage with returning starter Carson Beck alongside most of the team returning.
